bibl.title: Dispatch from Auselmo Jose Braamcamp
Despatches from United States consuls in St. Paul de Loanda, 1854-1893

revisionDesc.change: Creation of individual xml files, review, and addition encoding

div1.opener: Custom House Tariff for Loanda, Benguella, and Mossamedes
div1.p: Article 1: All goods and Merchandise imported from foreign ports into the Custom Houses of Loanda, Benguella, & Mossamedes, will pay the Duties as established in tables A & B.
Goods exported from said Custom Houses will pay duties as in table C

Article 2: All goods and Merchandise manufactured in the Kingdom, or in the adjacent Islands, will pay, when imported from there to the Custom Houses referred to us Article 1, 30% of the duties as established in the tables A & B

Article 3: Goods Merchandise re-exported from Portugal or, adjacent Islands to the Custom Houses mentioned in Articles, will pay
pay 70 percent of the duties, as established in tables A & B

Article 4: In order that goods and Merchandise to which Articles 2 & 3 refer can avail of the differential duties there etablished, they insist he accompanied with the despatches of the Custom House from whence they were exported, or re-exported
Article 5: It is permitted the re-exportation of goods from the Custom House of Loanda, paying an ad-valorem duty of 2 percent, without regard to the nationality of the exporting vessel.

Article 6: The transit of goods and Merchandise is permitted in "Franquia" from one to, another Custom House in the province, the necessary duty being paid according to the usage of the Custom
Custom House where the goods are despatched
Article 7: Goods or Merchandise, provincial or naturalised, having paid import duties according to Article 1, are allowed fee transit throughout the province
Article 9: Colonial produce from the ports to the North of Loanda, is free of import duty in the Custom Houses referred so in Article 1

Article 10: Goods and Merchandise re-exported from
from the deposits of other colonial or provincial Custom Houses mentioned in Article I will ne instilled to benefit by the rules in Articles No 2 and 3, according to where they come from and those taken out for consumption or naturalized in the same provinces except will enjoy the favor established by Article No 2
Article 11: Ad valorem duties will be calculated according to the value the goods may have in the market of the province

1st. The Importers or Exporters when they wish to despatch will sign a declaration with a description and value of said goods, in the sum which they way consider convienent. The declaration insist include all necessary information for the levying of duties

2nd. If the Custom House judge the declared value to be insufficient they
they will have the right to retain the goods, paying to the importer or exporter within the space of 10 days from date of declaration, 10% in addition to the value declared.

3rd. When however the Custom House do not find it convenient to have recourse to their rights, they can proceed to the valuation of the Goods by Exports, who will be named, one by the Director of the Custom House, the other by the Declarer; & in the event of their not being able to agree the Director of the Custom House will name a third expert from whose decision there will be no further appeal on either side

4th. If on examination of th experts they should show that the value of the merchandise does not exceed 10% over what had been declared the Custom House can in their choice excercise their rightm or have the
